title: Can i quit due to bounced checks?
question: my employer has money issues i have had 2 of my checks bounce then took 3 weeks to get back from the bank and redeposit it again, so i started taking them to his bank to cash them and countless times i was told they couldn't cash them due to insignificant funds in the account im just fed up working for him, does anyone knows if i can quit and get unemployment or what am i entitled to?
question_tags: Employment law for businesses,Business insurance,Workplace health and safety regulations,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Domestic violence and criminal charges,Employment,Unemployment compensation,Employee health benefits,Workplace safety,Termination of employment,State, local, and municipal law
answers:
In addition to unemployment benefits, you may have a host of wage and hour claims against your employer. If you are compelled to quit due to your employer's repeated failure to comply with the state wage and hour laws, then you may also have a claim for wrongful constructive discharge in violation of public policies. One issue you should carefully scrutinize before bringing any claim against your employer is whether your employer is financially solvent. If your employer is operating as a sole proprietor, then he is personally liable for the debts of the business. If he is solvent but failing to pay you compensation to which you are entitled, you can pursue claims against him as an individual defendant. If he is operating as a corporation (or other limited liability entity), then you can, of course, bring claims against the business form. If, say, the business form is a corporation and its shareholder—i.e., the gentleman for whom you work—does not really operate it like one (e.g., he underfunds it, he commingles the assets of the corporation with his own, he fails to observe corporate formalities, etc.), then you still may be able to reach him personally (using a legal theory known as “piercing the corporate veil”).

If your wage and hour claims are substantial, you should consult with an employment attorney right away. Otherwise, you also have the option of filing an unpaid wage claim with the Labor Commissioner or bringing a small claims action (assuming your damages are less than $10,000). Good luck.
If you quit, you would not be entitled to unemployment.

Yes, you should still be entitled to receive unemployment insurance benefits under such a scenario. In California, in order to be eligible for unemployment insurance (UI) benefits, you need to have been unemployed through no fault of your own.

When an individual files a claim for UI benefits, the EDD documents the reason the individual is no longer working, and includes it in the Notice of Claim Filed, DE 1101CZ, which is mailed to the last employer. The employer may also provide written information about the reason the individual is no longer working when responding to this notice.

If the individual quit, the EDD will conduct a telephone interview with the individual and the employer approximately two weeks after the claim is filed to determine whether or not the individual is eligible for UI benefits, according to state law and regulations.

California law provides that an individual who quits his/her job may be eligible for UI benefits provided there was "good cause" for leaving employment, and the individual made all reasonable attempts to keep their job (e.g., request of leave of absence or transfer). Once all reasonable alternatives to leaving have been attempted, good cause may include situations such as leaving work due to unsafe working conditions, leaving work based on a medical doctor's advice, or leaving work to protect oneself or one's child from domestic violence.

The EDD staff will determine on a case-by-case basis, whether the facts presented for the quit are "good cause" according to state law. Of course, the individual must also meet all other eligibility requirements before UI benefits can be paid.

The EDD’s law and policy guidelines regarding "Voluntary Quits" are available on the EDD Web site at:

http://www.edd.ca.gov/UIBDG/Voluntary_Quit_-_Table_of_Contents.htm

I would argue that you had "good cause" to quit because your paychecks were bouncing, and any reasonable person in your situation would also quit. "Good cause" is defined in Title 22, Section 1256-3(b):

"Good cause" exists for leaving work, when a substantial motivating factor in causing the claimant to leave work, at the time of leaving, whether or not work connected, is real, substantial, and compelling and would cause a reasonable person genuinely desirous of retaining employment to leave work under the same circumstances. Generally good cause for leaving work is decided on the facts at the time the claimant left work. Unless there is a timely connection between any alleged reason for leaving and the actual leaving, the employee has waived what might otherwise justify termination of the employment relationship and has negated the required causal connection between any given alleged reason for leaving and leaving. The claimant may submit several reasons for leaving work, some of which, when considered individually, do not constitute good cause. However, if one reason which is good cause is a substantial motivating factor in causing the claimant to leave work, the claimant's leaving is with good cause.
